text:
Thank you all for
coming, even though it's raining a bit this morning. So really appreciate
having me today.

So my name is Anhong Guo. I'm an assistant professor in
computer science and engineering at University of
Michigan, also affiliated

with the School of Information. So today, I'm going to talk
about some of our lab's work

on building and deploying
assistive technologies to make the real world
more accessible for people

with disabilities,
and towards this idea of personal accessibility
through personal assistive

technology. So let's start with
an example first. So the world is full
of physical interfaces

like microwaves,
information kiosks, thermostats, and
check out terminals.

And many, many objects
around us are also acquiring digital interfaces. Even our digital electronic
toothbrush, cooking pots,

they all have a bit
of a screen and some controls that you can
use now, and they're also acquiring touch screens.

So I want to ask you to think
about what kind of assumptions

are these devices making. So, for example, if we think
about you run into this kiosk,

what kind of ability assumptions
are they making for you to be able to interact with it?

The user can change
some parameters?

OK. So the user needs to be able
to control it, in some sense.

Anyone else? Yeah? With the screen,
you definitely have to be able to see
the [INAUDIBLE].

Yeah. You have to be able to see. If it makes sound, you should
be able to hear and understand

the sound and speech. And also, it requires you
to be able to lift your arm,

touch the interface,
and also lift precisely on the same point
within a time span.

So there are all
these assumptions that are making based on this
very simple user interface.

So although these
kind of interfaces are wonderful for
some people, and they

have some benefits of
being more flexible, they are also increasingly
incomprehensible and unusable

for others due to their
ability assumptions. So they require good vision,
hearing, speech and fine motor

abilities. So we have figured
out ways to make

we have self-voicing devices
like talking microwaves and clocks and scales that the
user is able to interact with,

and the device will read
out what is being clicked.

And, for example, if
someone is blind and also deaf, or deaf-blind people,
tactile markings or Braille

augmentations can make these
devices more accessible. So people can use
their tactile sensation

to understand and
operate these machines. So how do we make
things accessible today?

So physical objects
can be designed to be accessible
for certain people.

And on the other hand,
the digital information can be accessed through
assistive technologies. So we have screen
readers, we have

voice controls, and
physical controllers and many other types of
assistive technologies. So to give you an example
of assistive technology,

so here is screen
reader, which is a commonly used assistive
technology for blind people.
Let me play a clip. [VIDEO PLAYBACK]

- Drag your finger around
the screen to explore. - Settings, app store,
reminders, mail, FaceTime.

- This works with almost any
word, feature, or app name. [END PLAYBACK] So with this
accessibility layer--

and this works on mobile
devices and also on desktop-- users are able to interact with
a lot of digital information.

And another example of assistive
technology for deaf and hard of hearing people
is closed captions.

So here, I show you how
closed captions work back in the day on television,
and also on YouTube,

of a video of Michael
giving a talk at Michigan a couple of years ago.

So we currently have created
accessibility and usability guidelines to help
companies design

products to make
things accessible that are usable by more people. However, to make
things accessible,

it requires each product
to follow a set of-- follow these
guidelines, such as we

have perceptible information,
tolerance for error, flexibility of use. These, you might have learned
in universal design principles,

and we have alt text for images. We have closed captions for
videos and audio descriptions

for videos, audio
description for video. So these are all amazing
tools and guidelines

that we can use to make physical
and digital information more accessible. However, in reality,
there is still

only a very small
percentage of products that are actually accessible. So why?

So as pointed out
in a recent paper by Gregg Vanderheiden
and co-authors, it is almost impossible to
make each thing accessible

using this paradigm. So the reason is that we
have all of these guidelines,

but the current
guidelines have hundreds of individual
requirements in them,

requiring every single
developer and company to follow each guideline
to improve their products.

Yet these guidelines still
does not cover all the people with all kinds of types,
degrees, and combinations

of disabilities. And so essentially requiring
each product team and company to make their own product
accessible for all people

is not going to work. And I will add that anything,
especially the devices

that I showed you, anything
physically situated in the real world, like the
kiosk that's already there,

like the microwave that's
already put into a kitchen, they have to make assumptions
about the user, and it's fixed.

So think about the
chair you're sitting on. That chair is not
uniquely designed for you.

So even though
you can sit in it, it's not the most
comfortable for you. It's designed to work with
maybe 95% of the population,

but it doesn't work with
your needs the best. So anything physically
situated is often fixed

and have to make
assumptions about the user. And even though,
let's say, you can

add screen readers
and assistive touch and all these assistive
technology on a cooking pot

or anything with a
display, that is also not going to work because, first
of all, the cost consideration,

but also if you are familiar
with assist technology, you know that people
make deep customizations

on their assistive tools. They customize the gestures,
the settings, for themselves.

So there is no way for you to be
able to interact with something that's in the real world
and be able to have

it adapt to your needs
directly in the most deep, personalized way.

So to address
this, one framework is ability-based design.

Some of you might be
familiar with this. So ability-based
design, the goal

is to design things to
accommodate the user's ability. So the system that we call
a ability-based system

can adapt based on the user. So in some sense, the current
digital accessibility ecosystem

is kind of already
designed in this way. But breaking this down, I
think ability-based systems

have, really, two parts. One part is the physical and
digital objects to be accessed,

and the other part is the
assistive technology layer that work with those information
to present them to the user.

So I think in the context
of digital objects, such as mobile, web,
this makes sense, right?

So you can surface the
information in one way, and the user is able to
use their own assistive technology to work with it.

But if it is accessing
the real world, this often fail because the
physical infrastructure is often

rigid and cannot adapt. So our lab has been
working towards this vision

of personal
assistive technology. So I draw from
mainframe computing,

where, often, many users
access the same one device.

And we transformed from
that to personal computing, where it really enabled
users to consume, create,

and innovate by themselves. And mapping this to personal
assistive technology,

the idea is personal
assistive technology aims to empower people
with disabilities

to be able to access the
physical and digital world in their own terms, using
their preferred devices

and modalities, and be able
to leverage their domain

expertise to create
and customize technology for themselves.

So I'm going to show you a
couple projects that kind of map to how we think about this.

So using the same
illustration, now we are kind of moving this
assistive technology

part closer to the user. And thus, it becomes
more personal,

allowing it to access the rigid
physical and digital objects

out there that's already
in the real world. So I'm going to show you
a few examples of how

personal assistive
technology will be able to let people use their
own devices and modalities

and augment their environments,
as well as enable people with disability to make their
own assistive technology

and leverage broader context. So I will start
with the first ones.

So going back to this example,
making all of these interfaces accessible has been the
long-standing challenge,

and especially because
there is already a huge legacy problem
of these devices already in the real world.

They are not connected
to the internet and the user is
not able to control

them using a different device. So in our prior work, we
have developed systems

to interpret these interfaces,
either static or dynamic, and enabling blind people to
independently access them.

So to show you, so similar to
how the iOS screen reader work,

the user is able to move their
finger on the digital interface to hear what is
underneath their finger.

We can map that experience
to the physical interface. [VIDEO PLAYBACK] - Kitchen timer.

Kitchen timer and two, two
and five, five and two, two and five, two and one,
one and two, one and two.

Two. [END PLAYBACK] So, as you can see, when
the user moves their finger on the physical interface,
the system, this lens,

will be able to provide
real time feedback of what is underneath the
user's fingers, kind of mapped to how
a screen reader work

for digital information. So here is also
showing you a range

of interfaces that this
approach can work on. But the idea here is
that we're able to bring

the amazing affordances
of digital accessibility into the real world, and we
are able to allow the user

to use their own device and
their own preferred modality to access such information.

So think about if this user
prefer a faster speech, or this person prefer
tactile feedback,

or this person may use a
different assist technology to get the output, they
are able to transform

what is in the real world, what
is the information that they need to access in the
physical environment

into this preferred modality. And this device, this
smartphone they have, is really know them the best.

They have all the contacts and
understanding about the user's abilities and preferences.

So about two years
ago, in summer 2023, we deployed this app on the iOS
App Store and have had about 500

people use this for 1,000
different interfaces. And then subsequently,
maybe coincidentally,

Apple added a feature in
iOS accessibility settings.

OK, so you got the
idea that, the user is able to use
similar interaction, although it still doesn't read
what is under your finger.

You have to show what is
first above your finger, and then know how much to
move up to activate it.

So building on
this lens, we then develop a series of extensions
to extend the capability

of what kind of interfaces and
in what modality the user can access.

So first, we developed this
extension called Facade, which enabled blind people to
create these 3D-printed tactile

overlays for their
inaccessible appliances. So they can take a picture of
this interface with a reference

image, like a dollar bill or
a credit card that you know the absolute dimension
and features,

then you can use this to
retrieve the button information

and be able to generate a
3D-printed overlay that the user can then retrofit and
augment their appliance.

So this lets people augment
their own environments using this approach.

And furthermore,
we also extended this to work with more
dynamic touch screens.

So what we did is we used
the videos that people

interact with this machine. Maybe you used a
coffeemaker to order latte,

and somebody else go in and
really change the settings. And gradually, we can
collect those videos and be able to reverse-engineer
this state machine of how

this machine works and we are
able to present this using an audio interface
to a blind user

so that they can specify
what operations they want, and then the system is able to
guide them to complete that task

step-by-step. And more recently, we developed
a phone case extension

that we call BrushLens that
allow both blind users and also motor-impaired people, people
with difficulty with fine motor

control, to be able to
access touch screen kiosk. So the problem we're
trying to solve here

is that in the previous
extension that a blind user is able to use the touch
screen using the system,

the user still has to be really
precise in moving their finger following this audio guidance. And we found that
sometimes causes

challenges because that if
the UI is kind of particularly cluttered, the user
may make mistakes

and it might take a
lot of back and forth. So the problem we're
trying to solve is, OK, how about we can
use a hardware interaction

proxy to automatically perform
the actuation for the user so that the user can just
focus on broad strokes,

like brushing on this interface,
without worrying about the very fine motor control,
and then it can

delegate to this system to
perform the precise actuation. So let me play this clip.

[VIDEO PLAYBACK] - We present BrushLens, a
hardware interaction proxy to make touch screen devices
more accessible for people

with diverse abilities. BrushLens uses multiple
actuators to touch the screen.

It automatically determines
when to activate the actuator and precisely touch the
screen on behalf of the user.

We show the brushless with
solenoid and auto clicker actuators. Visually or motor-impaired users
can use the BrushLens accessible

interface on their smartphones
to explore and interact with inaccessible touchscreens. [END PLAYBACK]

So in this case, we built
two different phone cases.

One is with mechanical
actuators that can work with physical buttons,
capacitive or conductive

screens, and then the
other with these auto clickers that you can
actually see that is often

used in mobile farms. So people in mobile farms,
you have smartphones running

a TikTok video,
and then you have this connected to auto
clicker and automatically a bunch of videos.

So these automated methods. So we bought a bunch of those,
and we built the phone case to be able to change the
capacitance dynamically,

and then when the user is
brushing on the screen, it's able to just provide
the touch at the right moment

for the user. So the idea here is
that-- if you see, there are two different modes.

So one mode that's
supporting blind users is able to map the functions
that the user is trying

to perform onto an interface
that they can use voiceover to control.

On the other mode, to support
people lack fine motor control,

we're able to create a custom
interface that augments, that magnify the buttons
that's close to where

the phone is so it makes
it easier for the user to activate it. So in this approach,
if you think

about how this brings
that interface closer, this assistive technology
closer to the user,

is like this interface can
really know what the user needs, whether they need motor
support or visual support

or other kinds of support, and
be able to translate whatever

the user's ability and
perform interactions that's kind of assumed by that physical
object, or in this case,

the touch screen out there.  So this line of work
on providing assistance

for dynamic physical interfaces
can also be very broadly augment

and be extended to augment
how people generally interact with touch
screens in the real world.

So, for example,
when configuring complicated medical
devices or when

interacting with machines
in a different language, these guidance can
also be provided through a augmented
reality overlay.

It doesn't need to be
audio or haptics by itself. So these overlays
can be in the form

of visual indicators,
animated instructions, or interface simplifications.

So we also kind of explored
some authoring tools to create interactive AR
tutorials through narration

and demonstration. So in this case, using
the same backbone

of how we model the
interface structure, we're able to provide
a step-by-step tutorial

to guide the user to perform
operations on this printer.

So any questions so far? Yeah? What is the class of people
with motor challenges

that can't use a touch
screen, but still could hold the phone
consistently enough

to be able to swipe it
over, like a touchscreen? So I would say it doesn't map
to a particular condition,

but we recruited participants
who are able to, for example, rest their arm on
the screen and they

are able to move
their hand around, even though it's not in a
smooth, kind of zigzag motion.

But it reduces the
error rate a lot, and the users are able to
complete the task using
this kind of augmentation. Yeah?

I've got a question. Yeah. So you motivated with
the personal computer, and one of the weird ironies
is that the personal computer

wasn't very personal. It was very generic. It was just cheap enough
that everyone could get one. But I feel like your pitch
here is about, essentially,

mass customization
a little bit more. Is that fair? Yes. I think with the
personal computer,

the kind of analogy
I'm also drawing is you can access the
same content on the web

by using very
different extensions. So you can change
your contrast, you

can have it read out
at the same time, you can use dark
mode or light mode, like many other extensions
that you have on your browser

or on your computer. So you can have
these customizations that really work for you.

And this is a device
that's personal to you, that then you can use this
to access the vast amount

of information out there. So I can install stuff
on it, basically? Yeah. Yeah?

You mentioned the
microwave overlay. Was the idea to take
a picture and then

ship it out to some third
party, and then receive it? Or was the person supposed to
[INAUDIBLE] it on their own?

Yeah, that's a great question. So when we did the
project, that was--

I think digital fabrication
is, in parallel, advancing. And I think the vision is
that a blind user may not have

a printer at home, but
they may, in the future, have a 3D printer at home. But there are a lot of
accessibility challenges

in how to configure that,
how to remove the support material, and all that. But when we reach
there, this is something

that the user can do
completely by themselves or with a caregiver at home.

But for some of these devices,
we printed in the lab, or we use a service, like 3D
Hubs, and then we are able to--

the video actually
you saw is when they are about to
print your object,

they will send
you a link and you can watch the live stream
of how it's being printed. It's pretty cool. Yeah.

Yeah? I really like the
idea of thinking about changing the product
and making it more accessible

versus these personal devices. And I was wondering if there are
opportunities or ways to think

about approaches that are
hybrid or meeting both ways, like perhaps the product
provides some of metadata that

makes the personal device-- makes it easier for the person
to still retain customizability,

but gain the types of
underlying digital information or assumptions about
the product that

enables it to maybe do more? Yeah. So that's a great point. So eventually, for
this whole ecosystem

to work to make all, let's
say, 99% of the devices

or information accessible,
it requires the collaboration between all of these terms. But, for example, each
individual company

who is serving this information,
they don't have to become-- So this is the pointed out by
Gregg Vanderheiden's paper,

is they don't have to have a
dedicated accessibility team to make it accessible for
every single population,

but they can just
serve this information in the right way
that can be consumed by this general information bot.

So that's what they say. So the structure
that they propose is there is this info bot, and
there is this UI generator.

So with these two
in combination, then you are able to pair
them to work well.
Yeah.  OK. So let's move on.

So I've just showed
you a few examples of how we empower
people with disabilities to be able to access
physical information using

their preferred
device and modality. So next, I want to ask you,
these assistive technologies,
who developed them? Who designed them? Apple? Apple? Google?

Companies and maybe individual
researchers and product teams? So they are developed by
designers, developers,

and researchers. And, in practice,
these technologies

are typically designed
for common use cases in order to maximize
their broad applicability.

Just like your
chair, so it's trying to fit a majority
of the population.

But with this goal to
maximize broad applicability, the consequence is that they
become one-size-fits-all

and often inflexible,
and oftentimes, they are falling short of
supporting the unique needs

and preferences of end users. So the end users is not
able to make changes to these technologies to really
make it work for themselves.

So we conducted a series
of qualitative studies with blind participants
to understand

what are the situations that
there are these breakdowns, and how do blind people
want to customize or create

new solutions. And so we found that
people are already putting in significant
efforts to create

workarounds to try to adapt
to these long tail of needs. But existing workarounds
are often very tedious,
overwhelming, and ineffective.

So to illustrate this, I
will walk through one example given by our
participant, where they

want to use the AI
application SeeingAI developed by Microsoft to sort mail.

So what they do is,
they pull up this app using the short text
mode, and then they

aim the camera to
scan this envelope. So they want to figure out,
OK, are these mail for me

or for my family or for others? And so when they
do this scanning,

instead of just reading
out the information that's relevant for them, which is,
in this case, just their name,

they get all of the-- they get frustrated
by all the information that the app will provide.

And oftentimes, because
of camera aiming issues, it will kind of repeat
over and over again and they were not able
to complete this task.

So in response to
this, participant imagined being able to create
assistive technology on top

of SeeingAI that's just able
to tell them this information that they want,
which is their name.

And this is just one example
of how a blind participant is engaged in this design
process, this ideation process.

And so we observed
in this study a range of breakdowns and strategies
that people have been using.

So, for example, they want to
find just their name or address, just the expiration
date of the product,

or just the number
of an incoming bus. So there is actually a
huge variety of things that people want to
filter that they are not

able to do with the
kind of general purpose OCR or text-reading
applications today.

And also, blind
people often have to switch between multiple
services to achieve one goal,

like, for example, when
one of our participant was sorting mail using
in different languages,

some are in English,
some in Arabic. So they prefer they
have this kind of trick

of using CGI to read the
mail if it is English,

or use EnvisionAI
if it is in Arabic. So they know like this kind of
work well in that situation.

So they have to
manually do this. So they use one, they figure
out what language it is, and then they switch
to the other app.

Or in another case,
when a blind user is getting a scene description
from a generative AI

service, such as Ema
AI powered by GPT-4o, they have very
detailed strategies

of dealing with these
potential AI errors, like in high-stakes
situations, they will cross check with other
AI services like Cloud

or sometimes fall back
to human assistance. And they also kind of often
layer multiple services.

So, for example,
when blind people are navigating
unfamiliar spaces, they will use a combination
of multiple applications

such as Google Maps to get
directions, BlindSquare to know more about
the landmarks,

and also Oko to specifically
cross sidewalks. So the user is already
doing this kind

of manual process of
switching and combining different applications and
different services together.

So from cases like this,
as well as from prior work, we know that blind
people, in this case,

they are really
the domain experts in envisioning, designing and
hacking assistive technology.

But because of the current
limitations in this design and hacking process, individual
needs often become unaddressed.

So our goal is to
imagine, how can we empower blind people to leverage
their expertise and creativity

to be able to create custom
mobile assistive technology to address these needs?

So instead of they have
to channel these needs to a developer or
a company, and then

the companies create
something that can work with a range of
needs, what if we can give

the tools to the people and they
can create their own solutions?

So that's what we're imagining. So we are going beyond
consumption, but also

to creation. And personal
assistive technology here also aims to empower people
to leverage their expertise

to be able to create
technologies for themselves. So, essentially, this
part, they can change it

and they can create
this themselves. So going back to
Michael's question now not only they
can install things,

maybe they can make
those extensions and program those extensions.

So end-user
programming is a method that supports non-professionals
to create software artifacts

to be able to achieve their
goals in their own domains of expertise. It's potentially
suitable for this goal

that we're talking
about, but it is critical to address
the challenges, to make these end-user
creation processes

and tools approachable,
accessible, and expressive

enough for blind people. So the traditional paradigm
of end-user programming

is often too high of a
barrier for blind people to be able to create
assistive technology. So we need to figure out where
is the right abstraction.

So that's what we investigated
in our recent work so that blind

people could create filters,
such as "find my name on an envelope" to
just filter their name.

Or in the case of
sorting grocery, they can create something like
find data on grocery item.

So let me show you
once this program is created, how does it work.

[VIDEO PLAYBACK] - --runs the program. Pause running. Button. No date found on
grocery product.
Found date-- January 10, 2024. Brown. Found date-- January 10, 2024.

Yellow orange. [END PLAYBACK] So the user is able to run
this program called "find DATE on GROCERY ITEM" and then aim at
the packages or the grocery that

they have, and be able to turn
around and hear this live update of just the right
information they want.

So to develop this application,
we have three design goals.

So we want to make
it expressive. What that means is it
should be able to support a wide range of needs, and also
be able to easily extend it

into more kind of models
and tasks in the future.

And second is to
make it approachable, which means that
for blind people who

have very limited or no
programming experience, it should be
understandable to them,

and they still provide
easy entry points for them to be able to create
and make changes.

And finally, is
accessibility, which means that on the one hand, it
should be accessible to screen

readers so blind people can use
them, but on the other hand, it should also provide
sufficient contextual

information that help people
understand what's going on so even when the object
they are trying to find

is not in the field of view, it
should still provide surrounding context to help
them aim the camera and eventually
get the task done.

So in order to
make it expressive, we used all the
scenarios that apply

in this case in the
previous qualitative study. And we derived this
program representation

to support this kind of visual
information filter task. So this program followed this
pattern of "find something

on something." And each thing can
have adjectives on it that can denote color, location,
or size, or other attributes.

So with this very
simple structure, "find something on something,"
people are able to create

assistive programs to find
the number on the bus, to find the largest
text on the a poster,

or find the address
on an envelope. And this can also be easily
extended in the future

to support new models
and object classes, as well as maybe alternative
terms of "find" or [INAUDIBLE].

Yeah? Those dropdowns, are
those pre-populated or is that a closed vocabulary? Like "license plate,"
was that built-in,

or is that something
that end-user offered? Yeah, I will show you that. But those will depend on
the models that you plug in.

For example, if you use
Yolo, it will give you a set of object classes and
the user can choose from that, or if you use a combination
of different models,

then you can have
a more variety. Or if you use a VLM, then it's
more flexible in that case.

Yeah. So when running the
filtering programs, the program application will
iteratively find the items

and then provide the
information to the user. And when the target
object or maybe the number

is not found but
the bus is found, it will also provide
contextual information to help the user know what
is happening right now,

and maybe they see
that grocery item, but then they keep turning
to find the expiration date.

And one kind of side effect
we found in our study is that this actually may
reduce the hallucination

from VLM models. So if you just ask
the model a question, then sometimes it's able
to tell you something

that's not part of this image. But using this more
structured filtering approach, plug this into a
visual language model,

it's actually be able to
reason better about, OK, this is what I see, and that's the
number that's within this box,

not the number that's
somewhere else, maybe on a different vehicle.

Yeah, so we'll find the bus
and then find the numbers, and it will read these
things to the user

and the user can make changes. So in order to support
approachability

and accessibility, so how
do we support the user be able to create
these applications, is we develop a set of
multi-modal end-user programming

interfaces. So there are
block-based programming, there is natural
language programming,

and there is
programming by example. So in the block mode, users can
create the program just by using

a drop down, similar to how you
may configure an iOS shortcut or a IFTT,
if-this-then-that, programs.

So this gives you the most
control and most precision, but it will take a
bit longer because you

have to navigate through
all of these interfaces. And then in the
second question mode,

the user can just
speak their question. Oh, I want to find
number on the bus. I want to know what is my name.

Is this mail for me? And then we can use
fine tuning and be

able to generate candidate
programs for the user, and then they can continue
to edit it and use them,

if they want. And the third mode
is explore mode.

So this mode kind of takes
inspiration from programming by example. So the user can
first aim the camera

at the scene or this object
and get a bunch of output. And then once they
hear something

that they want, they can later
go back and select that item, 73, that, OK, I know
that's the bus number,

so I want to create this
program related to this. Then it's able to generate
a program using the tree

representation of the scene and
be able to go back and generate

this program. And then it will become
"find number on bus." So these are the three
different user creation

methods that we created. So we then conducted a user
study with 12 blind participants

to see whether this
approach really work and be able to support
accessibility use cases that

were not possible before,
and what are the preferences and trade-offs of people using
these three different creation

methods. So what we found is that each
of these creation interfaces

actually have their own
strengths and challenges. So for block mode, although
it takes more time,

it's generally a bit
more time-consuming, participants appreciate
that it was very precise and give them the control
over the final program.

This mode is especially useful
when they have something in mind that they want to create.

And for question
mode, participants found it to be very intuitive. You just speak what
you want, and then it's

able to potentially help you
generate the programs that can match the user's goal,
although sometimes the output

was not what they
intended and it might take more back
and forth for the user. So I think this is not
the ultimate form of how

the natural language
mode should look like, but I think there's more work
to be done to how you transition

between these multiple different
ways of creating this program to be able to best
match the user's intent.

And then third, for
the explore mode, participants found
that it is particularly helpful for
situations of unknown.

So they aim the camera,
they may discover something they didn't know before,
or some attribute that they didn't
think about, and they

are able to use
those in the programs to make it serve their needs. So what this means is that
providing these options,

a combination of
multiple options to users is kind of important to make
this end-user programming

possible and approachable for
users with a range of use cases and abilities.

So, as participant four put
it, "It's all contextual.

It depends on what
you want to do. I would use different
methods based on what I know about the environment.

If you already have an
image you're working with, for example, you
want to explore it, then that's what you will use.

It really depends
on the situation." So again, this
kind of highlights

that you need to provide
multiple different modalities and ways for the user to be
able to create an author that

may best suit their kind
of technical background or what they are
trying to do in situ.

And finally, participants
see the benefit of using this approach. And I think I really like
this quote that says, "It all

comes down to providing choice. Ultimately, you are
putting the information available in the
person's hands to choose.

It is creating modularity
to access the information. I wish more creators or
assistive technology companies

thought about how can we take
these pieces of information and put it in the hands of the
people who need it so that they

can then modify it and change
it and make it their own."

So going back to these different
strategies and breakdowns that we identified in the

the tool that I just
showed you support this first gap of

does not support a
specific use cases. But looking to the

so this last example

can generate live
visual descriptions that are adaptive to the user's

visual and auditory context. So what you see here is that
as the user is moving around,

if they are turning very quickly
or if they're walking quickly,

or the visual scene is
changing very quickly, then we provide bits and

And then the user start to
focus on a certain object or a certain scene
in front of them,

then more details will

GPT-4 or Beam AI to

just like it's not

they often have to
stop and ask questions and use this
turn-by-turn interaction to perform their task.

But here, in
WorldScribe, we're trying to map the description
to the user's context.

So the user can
specify their intent, and then based on how
dynamic the environment is

or their movement, we map
the description's granularity

or length to what they're
doing in the moment. And also we can manipulate the
presentation of the description.

So, for example, if music starts

to make it easier to hear.

Or if someone starts talking to

the description and without disrupting
what is happening,

what the user might be
doing that's more important. So overall, that's kind of--

I give you a bunch of
examples of personal assistive technology, and as we are
moving assistive technology

closer to the user and
becomes more personal and enable them to
create and modify

and use their preferred

this approach might be able to make it both
